thread.section_title: News & Opinion: U.S. Politics | Boston Herald
thread.title: Analysis: Benghazi questions linger
thread.title_full: Analysis: Benghazi questions linger | Boston Herald

author: Kimberly Atkins
title: Analysis: Benghazi questions linger
text:
WASHINGTON — The Republican chairman of the House Select Committee on Benghazi is the one who has been in damage control mode ahead of Thursday’s testimony by former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton — an event that has been engulfed in partisan controversy.
Those political flames have been lit largely by Republicans themselves, a point Clinton has been quick to point out on the campaign trail.
But Clinton is the one who will be in the hot seat Thursday, when she will still have a long day facing many substantive questions she needs to answer.
Yesterday saw Chairman Trey Gowdy trying to reset the narrative, telling fellow Republicans to “shut up” about the committee’s business, after House Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy seemed to concede that the House investigation is aimed at Clinton’s presidential aspirations.
Gowdy insisted on “Face the Nation” yesterday his committee is “much more focused on the four dead Americans than we are anybody’s presidential aspirations.” He said information continues to be uncovered, including newly discovered emails from Ambassador Chris Stevens, one of the four American casualties of the attack, repeatedly asking State Department officials for additional security at the consulate.
Democrats aren’t buying it. “He’s now trying to shift back to where we should have been all along, that is looking at the Benghazi incident,” Rep. Elijah Cummings, the committee’s top Democrat, said of Gowdy on the show.
But Democratic glee over Republican discomfiture and the political theater aside, serious questions await Clinton:
• Whether Clinton received or was aware of Stevens’ emails. Gowdy did not release the emails, but he assured that that question would be atop his list for Clinton Thursday: “I want to know why certain things made it to your inbox, Madam Secretary, but the plaintive pleadings of our own ambassador that you put in place for more security never bothered to make it to your inbox. I think that’s a fair question.”
• If so, why there was no response. Gowdy claims that Stevens even joked about his messages to the State Department being ignored. That is where the tens of thousands of deleted emails from Clinton’s private email server could hurt her the most. “Her biggest problem has always been herself,” GOP strategist Lisa Boothe said.
• Whether or not officials were adequately prepared to respond to the attack once it began. Gowdy said there was new information about preparedness that he could not disclose, but if put to Clinton she has to have an answer.
Gowdy needs to tread carefully, however. When men have questioned Clinton too aggressively in the past it has backfired, as in the case of her Senate debate with Rick Lazio.
“If Trey Gowdy comes at her too hard, she will win that in a rout,” said Democratic strategist Matt Bennett.
